data.title: Sonoma Valley Unified School District welcomes 34 new employees
data.meta_description: Sonoma Valley Unified School District will welcome 34 new employees, including five administrators and 20 teachers, when the 2024-25 academic year begins on Monday, Aug. 12.
data.text:
Sonoma Valley Unified School District will welcome 28 new certificated employees — including five administrators and 20 teachers — and six classified workers when the 2024-25 academic year begins on Monday, Aug. 12.

One of the new administrators, Troy Knox, had been serving as a member of the district’s board of trustees. He resigned from his board position after he was hired to serve as the director of special education, effective Aug. 1.

Knox has worked in leadership positions with Napa Valley Unified School District for the past 25 years.

“As a principal, Mr. Knox facilitated the development of specialized programs on his campuses, including special education preschool,” said Kristen Ugrin, the district’s director of human resources. “Mr. Knox is knowledgeable about special education services and programs, and fully understands the strengths and areas for growth for the special education department in Sonoma Valley Unified School District.”

Amber Williams also will be joining the district office, as coordinator of educational services.

“Ms. Williams has over five years of leadership experience and 22 years in education, most recently as an elementary principal,” Ugrin said.

Connor Snow, who has served as vice principal of Sonoma Valley High School for the past two years, will be the new principal at Altimira Middle School.

Melanie Harris has been hired as vice principal of Adele Harrison Middle School and Sarah March will serve as vice principal at Altimira Middle School.

The other new certificated employees consist of two nurses and one counselor.

Here is a look at some of the new teachers and other nonadministrative, certificated employees.

High Schools

Ken Cohen, who most recently served as an administrator at Yucca Valley High School in Southern California, will teach mathematics at Sonoma Valley High School. He was drawn to teaching in the Sonoma Valley Unified School District because his daughter works at a nearby school. Cohen received a bachelor’s degree from Florida State University as well as master’s degrees from Emporia State University and Grand Canyon University. He has a teaching credential in mathematics, a credential in administration and has served as an athletic director and a coach.

Jose Hernandez, the new music teacher at Sonoma Valley High School, last served as a music teacher for first through eighth grade students at Valley Vibes Orchestra in Sonoma. He earned an associate degree in arts and humanities from Yuba Community College, a bachelor’s degree in instrumental performance and music education at California State University, Sacramento and a preliminary teaching credential from California State University, East Bay.

Aaron McKown, a Glen Ellen resident with 20 years of teaching experience, will be teaching study skills classes at Creekside High School. He received a bachelor’s degree in political science form Pitzer College in Claremont, California, an MBA in human services at Brandeis University in Boston, and mild/moderate education specialist certification from Saint Mary’s College.

Max Potter, who will be teaching chemistry at Sonoma Valley High School, most recently served as a long-term substitute teacher in English and media lab at Kenilworth Junior High School in Petaluma. He achieved an associate degree in natural sciences form Santa Rosa College and then went on to earn a bachelor’s degrees in history as well as cellular and molecular biology from Sonoma State University.

Middle Schools

Chal Fanning, who last served as a counselor at George H. Flamson Middle School, will hold the same position at Altimira Middle School during the 2024-25 academic year. Fanning received a bachelor’s degree in horticulture from California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo; a master’s degree in coaching and athletic administration in exercise science from Concordia University Irvine and a master’s degree in student counseling and personnel services from Brandman University in Irvine.

Heather Haxton will join Altimira Middle School as a sixth grade mathematics teacher. She last served as a teacher of seventh grade and combined seventh and eighth grade classes at Summit Trail Middle School in Maple Valley, Washington. Haxton has a bachelor’s degree in interdisciplinary arts, with a minor in education, from the University of Washington, and a master’s degree in elementary education and teaching from City University of Seattle.

Katie Margreiter, a graduate of Sonoma Valley High School, will be teaching farm to table and science classes at Adele Harrison Middle School. She has been working as a substitute teacher for Sonoma Valley Unified School District and Hanna Center during the past 12 years while raising her children. Margreiter held her last full-time teaching position for 14 years at Templeton High School in California, where she taught agricultural science, agricultural mechanics, horticulture and animal science. After receiving an associate degree from Santa Rosa Junior College, she earned a bachelor’s and a master’s degree in agricultural education at California State University, San Luis Obispo, and a single subject teaching credential in agriculture science.

Elementary Schools

Jacqueline Echeverria, who most recently taught kindergarten students at Pueblo Vista Magnet School in Napa, will be teaching third graders at Flowery Elementary School, which she attended as a student. Echeverria received a double bachelor’s degree in Chicanola studies and early child development as well as a multiple subject teaching credential, all from Sonoma State University.

Anastacia Rodriguez Huerta will be a kindergarten teacher at Flowery Elementary School after serving as a kindergarten student teacher at the school in the 2023-24 academic year. She earned a bachelor’s degree in early childhood studies from Sonoma State University and expects to receive a multiple subject teaching credential from the school in December 2024. Before beginning the teaching credential program, she volunteered at schools in Vallejo, her hometown.

Elena Ingram will serve as a third grade teacher at Flowery Elementary School during the 2024-25 school year. In 2023-24, she was a student teacher of fourth graders at Gates Elementary School in Lake Forest, California, part at Saddleback Valley Unified School District. She previously received an emergency credential to teach seventh- and eighth-grade Spanish immersion classes at Unidos Middle School in Napa. Ingram attended University of California, Irvine, where she received a bachelor’s degree in psychology and Spanish, as well as a combined teaching credential, master’s degree and bilingual authorization.

Brenda Nicole Morales, who worked as a substitute teacher for Sonoma Valley Unified School District in 2023-24, will be a fourth grade teacher at Flowery Elementary School this academic year. Morales, who was born and raised in Sonoma, receiving a bachelor’s degree in child and adolescent development and counseling from San Francisco State University as well as a master’s in education and a multiple subject teaching credential from University of California, Santa Cruz.

Debora L. Rios has been hired as a first grade teacher at Flowery Elementary School after student teaching kindergartners and fifth graders there in 2023-24. Rios previously served as a substitute teacher for Sonoma Valley School District in spring 2023. She received a bachelor’s degree in Spanish and international studies from California State Polytechnic University, Humboldt and a teaching credential from Sonoma State University.

Districtwide

Anna Armfield, who has served as a pediatric and an adolescent psychology nurse, will be working as a districtwide nurse for Sonoma Valley Unified School District in 2024-25. After earning a bachelor’s degree in global and international studies from University of California, Santa Barbara, she received a bachelor’s degree in nursing from Metropolitan State University in Saint Paul, Minnesota.

Sean Boisson will work as a districtwide elementary school teacher. He received a bachelor’s degree in business from Sonoma State University and has served as a summer school aide at Prestwood Elementary School and a summer school staff member at Flowery Elementary School. Boisson also has coached baseball at Sonoma Valley High School for 12 years.

Carrie Brophy, who served at Willa Wellness Center in Petaluma (among and other places) during her 25-year nursing career, will work as a districtwide registered nurse (RN) for Sonoma Valley Unified School District. She received a bachelor’s degree from San Diego State University and her RN degree from San Jose State University Nursing School.

Additional Employees

Beth Espinosa will serve as a math teacher at Creekside High School. She most recently worked as a high school teacher and professional developer at Brightworks in San Francisco as well as a technology and interior designer at San Francisco Friends School. Espinosa earned a bachelor’s degree in education interdisciplinary studies at Humboldt State University and a multiple subject teaching credential from San Francisco State University.

Denny Lane is returning to the English department at Sonoma Valley High School after teaching English, social studies and theory of knowledge at Panyaden International School in Chiang Mai, Thailand. He graduated from Sonoma Valley High School and then received a bachelor’s degree and teaching credential from Sonoma State University. Lane subsequently taught at Sonoma Valley High School from 2015 to 2017.

Reach the reporter, Dan Johnson, at daniel.johnson@sonomanews.com.
